name: Guru Angad Dev Ji
excerpt: Guru Angad Dev Ji, born as Bhai Lehna in 1504, became the second Sikh Guru in 1539 after being chosen by Guru Nanak Dev Ji. He is best known for standardizing and popularizing the Gurmukhi script, strengthening the Sikh community through organization and service, and furthering the message of humility, discipline, and devotion. His stewardship established foundational institutions and practices central to Sikhism.

quickStats.label: Major Contributions
quickStats.value: Gurmukhi script, Organization of Sangat and Langar

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Born to a Hindu Khatri family in Matte di Sarai on 31 March 1504, Bhai Lehna was drawn to spirituality from an early age. He was deeply inspired by religious devotion and community service even before meeting Guru Nanak.

biographySections.label: Meeting Guru Nanak and Transformation
biographySections.value: Bhai Lehna encountered Guru Nanak Dev Ji in 1532. He became an ardent follower, displaying exemplary humility and dedication. Guru Nanak recognized his loyalty and spiritual depth, eventually choosing him as the successor and naming him 'Angad'—meaning 'one's own limb.'

biographySections.label: Standardization of Gurmukhi Script
biographySections.value: Guru Angad Dev Ji refined and popularized the Gurmukhi script, making Sikh teachings and scriptures accessible to the masses. This step united the Sikh community and preserved its scriptural identity distinct from the dominant Sanskrit and Persian scripts of the time.

biographySections.label: Strengthening Sikh Institutions
biographySections.value: He developed organized centers (Manjis) for Sikh congregational life and reinforced the importance of langar (community kitchen), with the help of Mata Khivi Ji. He also encouraged physical well-being, initiating wrestling and sports among Sikhs.

biographySections.label: Final Years and Succession
biographySections.value: Guru Angad Dev Ji spent his last years at Khadur Sahib, serving the community with compassion and humility. Before his passing in 1552, he appointed Guru Amar Das Ji as his successor, strengthening the tradition of spiritual leadership by merit.

spiritualLegacy.description: Guru Angad Dev Ji solidified the spiritual, linguistic, and organizational foundations of Sikhism, setting a model of obedience, humility, and selfless service for all future generations.
keyContributions: Standardized and popularized the Gurmukhi script
Organized and expanded Sikh congregational institutions
Promoted and institutionalized langar as a pillar of equality
Composed 62 hymns included in the Guru Granth Sahib
Encouraged physical health and sports within the Sikh community

modernRelevance.description: Guru Angad Dev Ji’s legacy resonates today in the centrality of Gurmukhi as a vehicle of Punjabi identity, the ongoing seva (selfless service) tradition, and the ideals of humility and inclusiveness.
contemporaryImpact: Gurmukhi script is the standard for Punjabi and Sikh scriptures
Langar and seva institutions serve millions worldwide
His life as an exemplar of humility and merit-based succession influences organizational leadership models in faith and society
Emphasis on physical wellness and character-building continues in Sikh and Punjabi culture

achievements.title: Standardized Gurmukhi Script
achievements.description: Refined and promoted Gurmukhi for Sikh writings, ensuring scriptural unity and literacy among Sikhs.

achievements.title: Strengthened the Sikh Langar System
achievements.description: With Mata Khivi, institutionalized the free community kitchen to promote social equality.

achievements.title: Expanded Sikh Institutions
achievements.description: Established Manji system to decentralize leadership and organize the growing Sikh community.

achievements.title: Composed Sacred Hymns
achievements.description: Authored 62 hymns now included in Guru Granth Sahib, continuing the poetic legacy of Guru Nanak Dev Ji.

quotes.original: ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਕੀ ਸੇਵਾ ਨਿਸਫਲ ਨਹੀ ਜਾਤੀ ॥
quotes.transliteration: Satgur kī sevā nisphal nahī jātī.
quotes.translation: Service to the True Guru is never fruitless.
quotes.context: Emphasizing the value of selfless service
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 475

quotes.original: ਹਰਿ ਕੇ ਨਾਮ ਬਿਨਾ ਸਭੁ ਦੁਖੁ ਪਾਇਆ ॥
quotes.transliteration: Har ke nām binā sabh dukh pāiā.
quotes.translation: Without the Name of the Lord, all is suffering.
quotes.context: Significance of meditating on God's Name
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 491

quotes.original: ਸਭੁ ਕੋ ਵਡਾ ਵੇਖਿਆ ਆਪੇ ਵਡਿਆਈ ਦੇਇ ॥
quotes.transliteration: Sabh ko vaḍā vekhiā āpe vaḍiāī dei.
quotes.translation: Everyone wants to be great, but greatness is bestowed only by the Divine.
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 1331

timeline.event: Birth of Bhai Lehna (Guru Angad Dev Ji)
First meeting with Guru Nanak Dev Ji; becomes disciple
Appointed as the Second Sikh Guru by Guru Nanak Dev Ji
Standardization and propagation of Gurmukhi, institutional reforms
Guru Angad Dev Ji leaves his body at Khadur Sahib

historicalContext.politicalSituation: End of the Lodi dynasty, early Mughal rule under Babur and Humayun; period of political instability in Northern India.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Entrenched caste distinctions, gender inequality, and religious orthodoxy prevailed. Literacy was very limited among common people.
historicalContext.significance: Guru Angad’s reforms facilitated social upliftment, inclusive community organization, and the creation of a script and identity distinct from both Hindu and Islamic traditions.

references: The Encyclopaedia of Sikhism (Punjabi University, Patiala)
Guru Angad: Second Sikh Guru by S.S. Kapoor
